Below The Contemplation of the Emptiness and Reality of the Provisional Dharmas, next is the praise of the three provisional contemplations. The provisional dharmas refer to the form aggregate.
This is the dharma.
The provisional feelings refer to the four aggregates.
Taking these two names is called the provisional name.
It has no substance of its own, and only exists based on others, so it is called provisional.
Moreover, the form aggregate is the dharma, and the feelings, etc. are the names. In all worlds, there are only names and forms, but now there are three separate explanations.
As for emptiness and reality, one is empty and two are real, which are mutually defined.
The dharma of the aggregates is empty, but ordinary people consider it real. Wisdom desires to understand but cannot be attained.
Only reality is emptiness, which is called emptiness and reality. This is the general meaning.
If the specific meaning is explained, within the three provisions, each has three contemplations.
The provisional dharmas are empty, which is the contemplation of emptiness. Emptiness is the same as the provisional and the real.
Every single form and every single fragrance is none other than prajÃ±Ä. This is the contemplation of the provisional. The single word contemplation is the contemplation of the middle.
Because emptiness and the provisional are the path of skillful means, they are not called contemplation. Only upon entering the middle way is it uniquely called contemplation.
Feeling and names and so forth can be understood in this way.
If explained from the perfect perspective, the three dharmas are emptiness, the provisional, and the middle. This is the illumination of both, the disappearance of both, and so forth.

The Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says: The dharmas are not real. Ordinary beings falsely imagine and discriminate, mistakenly thinking there is a person, like a dog looking into a well and barking at its own reflection.
There are no dogs in the water, only the reflection of forms, yet it gives rise to malice and jumps into the well to die.

Sentient beings are also like this. The combination of the four elements is called the body. The meaning of dependent arising gives rise to actions and speech. Ordinary beings falsely give rise to the notion of a person within this. This is the provisional of dharmas.
Giving rise to love and hatred, creating ignorance and pleasure, falling into the three evil destinies. This is the provisional of feeling.

Moreover, all dharmas are merely provisional names based on the combination of names, with no other names. For example, the combination of head, feet, belly, and spine is provisionally called a body. The combination of hair, eyes, ears, nose, mouth, skin, and bones is provisionally called a head. The combination of hairs is provisionally called hair, and the combination of parts is provisionally called a hair. The combination of particles of mud is provisionally called a part, and the combination of parts is provisionally called a particle. This is the provisional name.
Because of this provisionality, all dharmas are empty.

As for the three emptinesses and so forth, next praising the virtues of samÄdhi, because of the three provisional causes and conditions, one attains the three emptinesses. This is the sequential explanation of cause and effect.
Because of the provisionality of dharmas, there is emptiness. Because of the provisionality of experience, there is no appearance. Because of the provisionality of names, there is no action.
Therefore, the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says: Based on the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, one enters the gate of nirvÄá¹‡a.
The gate of nirvÄá¹‡a has three aspects, namely emptiness, no appearance, and no action, and so forth.

As for the gate of emptiness, contemplating that all dharmas are without self or possessions, all dharmas exist through the combination of causes and conditions, without an agent and without a receiver, this is called the gate of emptiness.

The gate of signlessness means that although the body is empty, there are still signs. Because people are attached to these signs, they cultivate signlessness. As it is said, looking up, looking down, bending, stretching, standing, walking, looking, and speaking, there is no reality in them.
Because the wind relies on consciousness, there is something that is done. This consciousness is extinguished, and because of moment-to-moment non-existence,
this male and female have a self. Because the mind lacks wisdom, falsely seeing the bones connected by skin and flesh, the mechanism moving like a wooden person, this is the gate of signlessness.
The gate of wishlessness means that even signlessness is nonexistent, this is called wishlessness.
Among these three concentrations and various dhyÄnas, if there is no [wishlessness], it is not called samÄdhi, because one regresses and falls into the cycle of birth and death.

It is said that one who can uphold pure precepts is called a bhiká¹£u, one who contemplates emptiness is called a practitioner of emptiness, and one who is always diligent and energetic is called a true practitioner of the Way. These three are able to reach nirvÄá¹‡a and attain the three gates of liberation.
The four truths and the twelve links of dependent arising - next, praise the truths and conditions.
These two have similarities and differences. They are the same because they are the Å›rÄvakas' elimination of views and thoughts.
They are different because their sharpness and dullness differ, and the number of broad and brief [teachings] differs.
The four truths are contemplated by those of dull faculties.
The MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra has four kinds of four truths, the arising and ceasing of the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching, which is not discussed here.
This sÅ«tra has three teachings and three kinds of four truths, namely the non-arising, immeasurable, and formless [teachings].
The four dharmas such as suffering are true and not false, and are called truths.
If suffering and accumulation are with outflows, and cessation and the path are without outflows, this is the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching.
If the four are all without outflows, this is the Shared Teaching.
If the four are both contaminated and uncontaminated, this is the distinct.
If the four are neither contaminated nor uncontaminated, this is the perfect.
The twelve links of dependent arising are contemplated by those of sharp and dull faculties.
Know that the Great Sutra also has four kinds, and within the four kinds, each has three distinctions:
First, the twelve links of dependent arising in the three periods of time; second, in two periods of time; third, in one period of time. The details are explained elsewhere.
All immeasurable merits are accomplished - the fifth concluding text can be known.
There are also eight hundred and forty million - below is the second listing of the assembly of pratyekabuddhas.
The text has four parts:
First, chanting the number; second, indicating the stage; third, praising the virtues; fourth, concluding.
The first text can be known.
Great sages and pratyekabuddhas - second, indicating the stage.
There are three distinctions:
First, the solitary enlightened one.
As in the past, a king entered the garden for sightseeing. In the clear morning, he saw the trees, forests, flowers, and fruits to be very delightful.
At that time, after the king had eaten, he immediately lay down, and the king's court ladies all competed to pick and destroy the forest trees.
When the king awoke, he immediately realized that all dharmas are impermanent.
If it is externally, it is a great sage pratyekabuddha.
Second, the pratyekabuddha who is a cause.
Appearing in the Buddha's world, hearing the twelve links of dependent origination, and severing the delusions of views and thoughts.
Third, the lesser pratyekabuddha.

This is a srota-Äpanna person who is born in the human realm. At this time, there is no Buddha, and the Buddha Dharma has already ceased. They are born seven times in the human realm and also in the heavens, and do not undergo eight births. They awaken on their own and attain the Way, and thus become a lesser pratyekabuddha.
Neither annihilation nor permanence is the third praise of his virtue.

Because the two causes in the past pull the consciousness and so forth, it is not annihilation. Because the consciousness and so forth cease, the three causes do not arise, and thus it is not permanence.
Moreover, because the three times continue, it is not annihilation. Because there is no self-nature, it is not permanence.
Moreover, following it, birth and death are endless, so it is not annihilation; going against it, ignorance is exhausted, so it is not eternal.
Four truths, twelve conditions below, the fourth is the conclusion.
Question:
In the previous list of Å›rÄvakas, it also says truths and conditions. Now praising pratyekabuddhas again clarifies them. Later listing bodhisattvas still says arhats. Why is this?
Answer:

In grasping enlightenment on a single object, the differences are self-evident. Three animals crossing a river, three birds escaping a net - the river is the same, but the animals are different; the net is one, but the birds are distinct.

Therefore the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra says, By contemplating with inferior wisdom, one attains the enlightenment of Å›rÄvakas; by contemplating with middling wisdom, one attains the enlightenment of pratyekabuddhas; by contemplating with superior wisdom, one attains the enlightenment of bodhisattvas; by contemplating with the most superior wisdom, one attains the enlightenment of buddhas.
It is precisely because the view of the principle is different that the truths and conditions are mutually spoken of.
Question:
Pratyekabuddhas appear in worlds without buddhas. Why are they now listed as part of the assembly that heard [the teaching] together?
Answer:
Pratyekabuddhas also exist in the world when a Buddha is present, they are simply included among the Å›rÄvakas.
As for the statement that they appear in worlds without a Buddha, this is in contrast to the Å›rÄvakas, it does not mean that there are no pratyekabuddhas in the world when a Buddha is present.
And nine million billion and below is the second listing of the assembly of bodhisattvas.
The text has five parts:
First, number; second, title; third, rank; fourth, virtue; fifth, conclusion.
The first part can be understood.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is the second, the title.
Bodhisattva means sentient beings with the mind of the Way.
MahÄsattva means great mind of the Way, also called great person or pioneer.

If one practices the six perfections with a mind of arising and ceasing, one will become a Buddha in three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas. This is the bodhisattva in the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching, whose mind is superior to the Å›rÄvakas but whose path is inferior to the arhats.

If one uses the mind of non-arising to sever the delusions of views and thoughts, retains the remaining habits, supports the vow to take rebirth, perfects the practices of the ten grounds, and is known to be like a Buddha, this is the bodhisattva of the Shared Teaching.

If one uses the immeasurable mind to practice immeasurable practices, purifies the Buddha lands, accomplishes sentient beings, has great compassion that is inexhaustible and great pity that is limitless, and attains the body of merit and virtue by being crowned with flowers, this is the bodhisattva of the Distinct Teaching.

If one uses the mind of non-action to contemplate afflictions, enlightenment, birth and death, and nirvana, as non-dual, non-separate, neither accomplished nor unaccomplished, this is the bodhisattva of the Perfect Teaching.
The ones listed here are correctly listed in the Shared Teaching, but also include the Distinct and Perfect Teachings.
All of them are arhats refers to the third level of understanding.
In the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching, the Buddha is an arhat.

Therefore, the Sutra of the Past Activities of the Buddha says, At that time, there were six arhats in the world, the five were the five people including Kauá¹‡á¸inya, and the one was the Buddha himself.

If in the Shared Teaching the three vehicles practice the ten grounds together, the bodhisattvas of the seventh ground are the arhats.ğŸ”½If in the Distinct Teaching, the bodhisattvas of the ten abodes who have severed the afflictions of the three realms are equal to the arhats.
If in the Perfect Teaching, the bodhisattvas of the ten faiths who have severed the afflictions of the three realms are also equal to the arhats.
Now all the arhats are the bodhisattvas of the Shared Teaching.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-sÅ«tra says, The wisdom and severance of the arhat is the non-arising forbearance of the bodhisattva.
The MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta-sÅ«tra also says, The great Dharma bodhisattva is called an arhat.
Question:
If they are all arhats, it has already been explained. Why is it clarified again now?
Answer:

Because the form of a bodhisattva has no fixed standard, sometimes the same as an ordinary person, sometimes the same as a Å›rÄvaka or pratyekabuddha. If not explained separately, I fear it will be confused with reality. I hope those who value the Lesser Vehicle will know that the virtue of a bodhisattva is equal to that of an arhat, and those who grasp at characteristics will realize that the path of a bodhisattva surpasses that of an ordinary person, so I explain it separately again.
The merits of true wisdom and below, in the fourth praise of virtues, first praise the merits of wisdom.

True wisdom illuminates emptiness, and skillful means wisdom illuminates existence. Because there is true wisdom, one does not dwell in saá¹ƒsÄra. Because there are skillful means, one does not dwell in nirvÄá¹‡a.
The previous explanation of the stage although says arhat, now this praise of virtues is different from the two vehicles, so it is explained separately.
The bodhisattva of the Shared Teaching possesses true wisdom in the seventh stage, and possesses skillful means wisdom in the eighth stage and above.
Practicing the Great Vehicle alone is next the praise of the vehicle.
The two vehicles have no share, so it is called the Great Vehicle alone. This praises the bodhisattva of the Distinct Teaching.
Four eyes praises the eyes next.
Since the bodhisattva practices are not yet complete, it should be the case that there is no Buddha eye.
In the Shared Teaching, one should know that it is like the Buddha, and by inference, the eyes are also like the Buddha.
In the Perfect Teaching, although the ten abodes of faith are the flesh eyes, they are called the Buddha eye.
Now, the four eyes refer to the bodhisattvas before the grounds in the Distinct Teaching.
Five spiritual powers praises the spiritual powers next.
They are fully endowed with the five, including the heavenly eye, but not the spiritual power of ending outflows.
In the Shared Teaching, outflows have not yet been severed, and in the Distinct Teaching, they are still not completely severed, so it only speaks of five.
Three insights clarifies the insight into past lives, the insight into the heavenly eye in the present, and the insight into ending outflows in the future next.
Insight is the same as penetrating insight.
Ten powers praises the powers next.
The Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says: The bodhisattvas have ten powers:

First, the power of firm resolve; second, the power of great kindness; third, the power of great compassion; fourth, the power of diligence; fifth, the power of meditation; sixth, the power of wisdom; seventh, the power of not being weary of birth and death; eighth, the power of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas; ninth, the power of liberation; and tenth, the power of non-obstruction.
As for the four immeasurable minds, next praise the mind.
Compassion can bestow happiness, compassion can eliminate suffering, joy can bestow the supreme happiness to sentient beings, like the above three minds let go of attachment and so forth.
As for the four analytical knowledges, next praise eloquence, which is the analytical knowledge of dharmas, meanings, etymologies, and inspired speech.
As for the four means of unification, next praise unification, which is giving, kind speech, beneficial conduct, and practicing what one preaches.
As for the adamantine concentration of cessation, next praise the elimination of afflictions.
The concentration of forbearance on the ten grounds is like a vajra, shattering the mountain of afflictions without moving itself, it is also called the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama samÄdhi and so forth.
All merits and below, the fifth is the general conclusion.
And there were millions and billions and below, the third is the listing of miscellaneous types of beings.
Because the names and forms within it are not one, it says miscellaneous types.
There are two parts: first, specific; second, general.
The specific part has four:
first, humans; second, gentlemen; third, gods; fourth, sages.
The first human is further divided into two: first, male; second, female.
The first has four:
first, number; second, name; third, virtue; fourth, conclusion.
The first, the number, can be known.
Virtuous ones who uphold the five precepts is the second, listing the names.
Five is the meaning of number.
Precepts are the meaning of prevention.
The Sanskrit word upÄsaka means lay male, because they give rise to pure faith in the Buddha's teachings.
It is also called one who serves closely, because they rely on the Three Jewels, serve their teachers and elders, and are never negligent.

Abstaining from killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct prevents the three bodily actions, while the precept against false speech prevents verbal actions, and the precept against drinking alcohol prevents both bodily and verbal actions.
The detailed explanation of the precepts is as explained in the Shilaparamita chapter of the Mahaprajnaparamita Sutra.
Tiwei Boli and others asked the Buddha:
Why don't you explain the four and six precepts for us?
The Buddha replied:

Five is the greatest number in the world. In the heavens, it is the five stars; on the earth, it is the five sacred mountains; in humans, it is the five internal organs; in yin and yang, it is the five elements; in the king, it is the five emperors; in the world, it is the five virtues; in color, it is the five colors; in the Dharma, it is the five precepts.
Abstaining from killing is paired with the east, which is wood. Wood is the lord of benevolence, and benevolence means nourishing life.
Abstaining from stealing is paired with the north, which is water. Water is the lord of wisdom, and the wise do not steal.
Not committing adultery corresponds to the West, which is gold. Gold is the lord of righteousness. One with righteousness does not commit adultery.
Not drinking alcohol corresponds to the South, which is fire. Fire is the lord of propriety. Propriety prevents mistakes.

Not speaking falsely corresponds to the center, which is earth. Earth is the lord of trustworthiness. One who speaks falsely is at odds with both sides and does not accord with the center. The meaning of the center is not to be biased or at odds.
One who is about to become a sage is called a worthy. This is a provisional name for one who practices the stages.
All practicing as arhats and below is the third praise of virtue.
Although their traces are the same as ordinary people, their roots are all arhats.
Ten grounds means there are three kinds:
If bodhisattvas and the two vehicles practice together, this is the common teaching.

First, the stage of dry wisdom; second, the stage of nature; third, the eighth person; fourth, the stage of views; fifth, the stage of thinness; sixth, the stage of separation from desires; seventh, the stage of already discerned; eighth, the pratyekabuddha stage; ninth, the bodhisattva stage; tenth, the buddha stage.
Relying on these ten stages, one becomes a lay Buddhist in the common teaching.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says, If a bodhisattva is equipped with the stage of dry wisdom, they will quickly realize enlightenment in the ten stages. And so forth.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra, fascicle 78, says, The stage of dry wisdom is of two kinds:
First, Å›rÄvakas; second, bodhisattvas.

ÅšrÄvakas, for the sake of nirvÄá¹‡a, diligently cultivate precepts and so forth, or practice the samÄdhi of contemplating the Buddha, the floating contemplation, and so forth. Although they have wisdom, they do not obtain the water of dhyÄna concentration, so it is called the stage of dry wisdom;
For bodhisattvas, it is from the initial arousal of the mind up to not yet attaining patient acceptance in accordance with the truth.
The stage of nature refers to the Å›rÄvaka from the stage of heat up to the stage of supreme worldly dharmas;
When bodhisattvas attain acceptance, they become attached to the characteristics of reality and do not give rise to wrong views, attaining the water of meditative concentration.

At the stage of acquiescence to the truth of the path, one attains the stage of the eighth person. The stage of the eighth person refers to the sixteen moments of the mind from the acquiescence to the truth of suffering up to the subsequent acquiescence to the truth of the path. For bodhisattvas, it is the acquiescence to the non-arising of dharmas, entering the stage of the bodhisattva.
The stage of vision refers to initially attaining the fruit of stream-entry, for bodhisattvas it is the stage of irreversibility.
The stage of thinness refers to the once-returner, because they have eliminated nine types of the suffering part in the desire realm.
For bodhisattvas, it is surpassing the stage of irreversibility, up to not yet becoming a buddha, and also thinning out the remaining habitual tendencies of eliminating afflictions.
The stage of separation from desire refers to separating from the craving of the desire realm and so forth, called the non-returner;
for bodhisattvas, due to the causes and conditions of separating from desire, they attain the five supernatural powers.
The stage of completion refers to the Å›rÄvaka attaining the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising, the unattached arhat;
for bodhisattvas, it is accomplishing the stage of buddhahood.

The stage of pratyekabuddhas refers to those who planted the causes for the pratyekabuddha path in past lives and now, with minor conditions, also contemplate the profound principle of dependent origination, and are called pratyekabuddhas.
The stage of bodhisattvas refers to those from the first ground of joy up to the Dharma cloud ground, all of whom are called bodhisattvas.
This borrows the names of the distinct teachings to name the common teaching.
The stage of buddhas refers to the dharmas such as the knowledge of all modes.

All bodhisattvas, within their own stages, contemplate the perfection of self-benefit, and within the stages of benefiting others, practice the perfection of benefiting others. Because of the perfection of these two things, it is called the stage of buddhas.
If it is the distinct teaching, then from the first ground up to the Dharma cloud, one practices alone and does not share with Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
According to this, it is the upÄsaka within the distinct teaching.
The perfect teaching is explained in detail.
Turning toward the perfection of the five-part Dharma body refers to the distinct teaching connecting with the emptiness of the common teaching.

By connecting the initial ground of the Distinct Teaching with the Shared Teaching, it prevents one from stagnating in the emptiness of form within the realm of desire, and turns the mind towards the Distinct Teaching to sever ignorance outside the realms, and accomplish the five parts of the Dharma body.
Praising the dedication.ğŸ”½As for complete, the five parts of the Shared Teaching's biased truth are incomplete.
The accomplishment of the correct contemplation of the middle way in the Distinct and Perfect Teachings is when the five parts are truly called complete.

The five parts of the Dharma body are: 1) the body of precepts, 2) the body of concentration, 3) the body of wisdom, 4) the body of liberation, and 5) the body of the knowledge and vision of liberation.
Question:
Why do bodhisattvas dedicate what they do?
Answer:
The benefits of dedication are the most excellent, therefore the Vimalakirti Sutra says dedication is the good benefit.
There are two kinds of dedication:
First, dedicating what one does to give to sentient beings; second, dedicating what one does towards the fruition of Buddhahood.
Immeasurable merits and below is the fourth summary.
And ten thousand and below is the second listing of laywomen of pure faith.
The text has three parts:
First, the number; second, the names; third, the virtues.
The first is understandable now.
Laywomen of pure faith is the second, the heading of the names.
The Sanskrit says upÄsikÄ, which means laywoman of pure faith.
All practicing the arhat and below is the third, praising the virtues, which is also the superior upÄsikÄ among the general and specific.
The text has two parts:
First, generally praising the ten grounds is understandable.
Next, just born and below specifically praises the merits in the ten grounds.
The text has two parts:
First, the correct praise.

One ground has three minds. From the tenth stage of faith, one begins to have the merits obtained in the first ground, which is the initial mind. The merits obtained by staying and not progressing are the abiding mind. The fulfilled merits that wish to enter the second ground are the final mind.
The Lotus Sutra also says well entering, emerging, abiding and so on.
Thirty merits of rebirth below, next is the conclusion.
And ten koá¹­is below, the second lists the assembly of householders.
The text has four parts:
First, number; second, names; third, virtues; fourth, conclusion.
The first is now known.
Seven wise householders is the second, listing the names.
There are two kinds of seven wise people:
First, the small vehicle, such as the five stopping and contemplating practices;

Second, the great vehicle, namely, those who have just begun to generate the intention for enlightenment, those who practice with characteristics, those who practice without characteristics, those who practice with skillful means, those of the severed lineage, those of the lineage of nature, and those of the lineage of the path.
All are in the stage before the grounds, and are called the seven wise people because they adjust their minds and accord with the path.
Householder means in foreign countries, one who has accumulated wealth up to the value of a koá¹­i is called a householder.
Now, this wealthy man is called a householder because he possesses the seven kinds of pure wealth, namely faith, giving, morality, learning, wisdom, conscience, and shame.
Virtuous conduct is complete and below is the third praise of virtue.
It means possessing all virtuous conduct, which is called virtuous conduct is complete.
Twenty-two categories praises the categories of the path.

Since it is before entering the path of seeing, there are only the four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts, four bases of supernatural power, five faculties, and five powers, totaling twenty-two categories.
Ten universal bases praises the ten universal bases, where base means place.
Blue, yellow, red, and white, earth, water, fire, and wind, the base of infinite space, and the base of infinite consciousness are called the ten.
Eight emancipations praises the eight spheres of mastery.

First, internally having the appearance of form, observing external forms as few; second, internally having the appearance of form, observing external forms as many; third, internally without the appearance of form, observing external forms as few; fourth, internally without the appearance of form, observing external forms as many; fifth, blue; sixth, yellow; seventh, red; eighth, white, and so on.
As for the eight liberations, next praise liberation.

First, internally having the appearance of form, observing external forms; second, internally without the appearance of form, observing external forms; third, observing pure form; fourth, the sphere of space; fifth, the sphere of consciousness; sixth, the sphere of nothingness; seventh, neither perception nor non-perception; eighth, liberation of the cessation of perception and feeling.
Question:
Since one has not yet attained the noble [path] through observation, why is it now praised as the eight liberations?
Answer:
Among the eight, one attains seven, but not yet the cessation of perception and feeling. Now it is praised from the perspective of the majority.
Question:
What is the meaning of liberation?
Answer:
Liberation means abandoning and turning away from [afflictions].

The first two abandon the mind of craving for form, the third abandons the mind of impure contemplation, the four formless [absorptions] abandon the mind of the lower stages, and the cessation of perception and feeling causes one to abandon the mind that takes all as objects.
Question:
What is the difference between liberation, mastery, and pervasiveness?
Answer:

That which is called liberation is abandoning, that which is called mastery is being able to subdue the objects, and that which is called pervasiveness is being able to expand and surpass the objects.
As for the three kinds of wisdom, next is the praise of wisdom, referring to hearing, thinking, and cultivation.
The first is the stage of dry wisdom, the next is the four good roots, and above the acceptance of suffering is called the wisdom of cultivation.
As for the sixteen truths, next is the praise of the contemplation gate, as explained above.
As for the four truths, next is the praise of the truth gate, also as explained above.
As for the four, three, two, and one level contemplations, next is the praise of the four gates, which are the four contemplations and acceptances.
From below, it is raised:
Heat is fourth, peak is third, patience is second, and the supreme worldly dharmas are first.
Four refers to the four good roots, three refers to excluding the stage of heat, two refers to excluding heat and peak, and one refers to excluding the first three.
Also, four refers to the four fruits, three refers to the three fruits, two refers to the two fruits, and one refers to the first fruit.
This is not the meaning of praise, and now I take the previous explanation.
Attaining the ninety forbearances is the fourth conclusion.
The text is in two parts:
First, a specific conclusion, second, a general conclusion.
Now, the first.
Some people say:
The thirty minds of the three sagely stages before the grounds, each divided into lower, middle, and upper, or the three levels of entry, abiding, and exit, add up to ninety forbearances.
Some people say:
The four, three, two, and one add up to ten forbearances. Based on the nine grounds of the three realms, each ground has nine levels, making ninety forbearances.
Also, it is said:

The twenty contemplations refer to the sixteen truths and four truths, and the contemplations in groups are ten, namely four, three, two, and one, totaling thirty. Each has three levels of lower, middle, and upper, forming ninety forbearances.
Now, the ninety forbearances are a separate conclusion.
In the sutra text, the virtues cannot be said to be many and different. It only speaks of fully possessing twenty-two types, down to four, three, two, and one;
The number has eighty-one types. From these dharmas come the four dhyanas, four formless [absorptions], and the concentration of cessation, totaling ninety forbearances.
Although the sutra does not have the text of the four dhyanas, etc., the meaning can be inferred as such.
All merits are accomplished is the next general conclusion.
There are also ten trillion is the third listing of celestial beings.
The text is in two parts:
First listing the form [realms], then listing the desire [realm].
The first text has four parts:
First, number; second, location; third, virtue; fourth, conclusion.
Now, the first.
Since there are tens of thousands of tens of thousands, it is said to be ten trillion.
Nine Brahmas and below, second, clarifying the location.

This sutra has three different versions. One version says, There are also ten trillion eighteen Brahma heavens, nine Brahmas, three pure heavens, three luminous heavens, and five heavens of joyful bliss.
Another version only says three pure heavens, three luminous heavens, and five heavens of joyful bliss.
